ldquoIt would also lead to the electoral wipe-out of the Tory Party in Scotland.In a statement he said he was ldquooptimistic about Scotlandrsquos long-term future and described unionists as ldquoweak and leaderless.Boris Johnson and his Tory Government represent values which are alien to many people in Scotland, driving more and more of them towards independence.ldquoBut victory for the independence movement is not yet in the bag, there is a lot more work to do to achieve our goal.The MSP said there had to be a second referendum ldquoto make progress and said that the SNP must put a second referendum during the next parliamentary letime as the ldquocentrepiece of its campaign.He continued: ldquo To underline the strength and clarity of the mandate, the SNP should agree the wording of that commitment with the wider independence movement and in particular invite the Scottish Green Party to agree an identical wording for their manesto promise of a referendum. That way the legitimacy of the pro-independence partiesrsquo joint mandate cannot be challenged.ldquoIf the Scottish people elect a pro-independence majority to the Scottish Parliament with a clear democratic mandate to hold an independence referendum, I do not believe that Boris Johnson would dare stand in the way of Scottish democracy.The economic case for Scottish independence, he said, must be ldquo completely re-written to take into account the challenges caused by the Covid- pandemic.He continued: ldquoThe case for independence needs to be updated as the world has moved on since .ldquoIt is dficult to see how we can re-build the Scottish economy without the tools available to independent nations, including a currency and central bank.:Doug Marr: SNP split risks damaging rise in Scottish independence supportldquoThe SNP also has to re-visit its policy for an independent Scotland to join the EU, which would lead to customs barriers between an independent Scotland and the rest of the UK.ldquoIt would make much more sense for an independent Scotland to join EFTA, which would secure access to European markets without the downsides of EU membership.Mr Neil has been an MSP since the establishment of the Scottish Parliament and held positions in cabinet under Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond..He has held four ministerial posts as Minister for Housing, Cabinet Secretary for Infrastructure, Cabinet Secretary for Health and Cabinet Secretary for Social Justice.After leaving Holyrood next year, he intends to continue his business interests and has vowed to continue to campaign for Scottish independence.

title: high-blantyre-primary-school-classes-self-isolate-positive-cases-covid-19
story: It was confirmed on Sunday evening that two pupils and a staff member had tested positive for the virus at High Blantyre Primary School.All iniduals were last in school on Thursday, August , with the staff member testing positive on August  and pupils on August .Pupils and associated staff of Primary  and Primary  have been asked not to attend school as a precautionary measure.:In full: Scotlands primary and secondary schools where there are cases of Covid-They will be offered testing on Wednesday, August  and asked to self-isolate until they receive confirmation of a negative result.Anyone associated with the schools supported class has been contacted directly by NHS Lanarkshires test and protect team.Health bosses say there is currently no evidence to suggest that there is transmission in the school, and sothe risk to the wider school community is low and the school will remain open to anyone who has not been contacted by contact tracing teams.NHS Lanarkshire is working closely with South Lanarkshire Council and Public Health Scotland with regard to these cases and has promptly identied close contacts.Dr Josephine Pravinkumar, NHS Lanarkshirersquos consultant in public health medicine, said: ldquoOur test and protect team will continue to contact anyone who may be affected. Public health advice is being given to these iniduals and they are being told to self-isolate and offered testing as required.ldquoThere is evidence that mixing socially in the community without maintaining physical distancing measures can transmit the virus. It is therefore important that people remain vigilant and follow physical distancing guidance.Dr Pravinkumar continued: ldquoWe are aware that there will be concern among both children and their parents at this time. We would like to reassure the local community that appropriate measures are being implemented.ldquoIniduals should stay off school or work and get testedthey or their close contacts experience any Covid- symptoms, such as a cough, fever or loss of taste or smell, eventhey are mild.Tony McDaid, executive director of education resources at South Lanarkshire Council, said: ldquoThe council is fully supporting the incident management team, led by NHS Lanarkshire, and its test and protect activity.ldquoWe will continue to respond to advice from NHS Lanarkshire and provide information and reassurance to parents and carers, pupils and staff. We fully understand that parents and pupils will be anxious."No blame is attached to anyone who is interviewed by Test and Protect but it is important that as much information as possible is given. In addition, support within school is available to any pupil who is anxious or has concerns.

title: kingspark-school-linked-cluster-rises-campus-remains-closed
story: Kingspark School in Dundee was the first school in Scotland to close its doors due to Covid since pupils ed to the classroom on August .The first positive case of an adult connected to the school was identied by NHS Taysides health protection team last Tuesday.Since then, cases have continued to rise, with health bosses confirming on Sunday that the cluster has now reached  -made up of  members of staff, two pupils and three community contacts.:Two Lanarkshire primary school classes to self-isolate after two pupils and staff member test positive for Covid-Now, a single positive case has been linked to the Primary A class at St Peter and Pauls School in Dundee, with another positive case linked toHappy Times out-of-school club at Downfield Primary School.Parents of all pupils in PA and the after-school club were contacted on Sunday evening by education staff to advise that their child should self-isolate for  days until September .Dr Ellie Hothersall, Consultant in Public Health Medicine with NHS Tayside, said:ldquoSince the identication of positive cases at Kingspark, a detailed contact tracing programme has been under way and these linked cases are being identied because of those concerted efforts of Test and Protect.ldquoWe must do everything we can to protect all of our communities against COVID- and that is why we have issued the guidance to self-isolate. By taking this action we are containing any further spread of infection.:In full: Scotlands primary and secondary schools where there are cases of Covid-ldquoWe know that this may cause anxiety to some parents and children but we must do everything we can to ensure we keep people safe.Paul Clancy, Dundee City Council Executive Director of Children and Families Services, said:ldquoI would like to reassure families that this action is being taken to keep everyone safe."This is our paramount concern and we cannot be complacent.

title: lockdown-scotland-country-wide-changes-august-24-aberdeen-easing
story: Nicola Sturgeon announced on Thursday that several leisure and entertainment venues can reopen on Monday, as long as physical distancing and hygiene measures are in place.Driving lessons and contact sports will be able to resume for the first time since restrictions were put in place in March.But the First Minister has urged Scots to be cautious as she announced the lting of restrictions on Thursday.:Aberdeen lockdown restrictions to be easedOn Saturday, Scotland recorded its highest rise in Covid- cases since May. The Scottish Government said there had been  positive cases in  hours.Speaking to the Scottish Parliament on Thursday, the First Minister said: ldquoThe prevalence of the virus continues to be at low levels in Scotland, but we are also recording more positive cases than three weeks ago and we have seen one signicant outbreak inAberdeenand a number of smaller clusters in locations across the country.ldquoI hope the re-opening of some services will be welcomed because we know it is essential to reduce the economic harm this virus is doing, but I hope people will also understand why, as we try to open services and keep them open, we must take firm action when rules and guidance are not being complied with.From Monday, some local lockdown restrictions in Aberdeen are set to be lted.

title: letters-need-managed-full-opening-economy-not-extension-furlough-scheme
story: Covid- is simply an addition to the list of health risks we have to prudently manage as we go about our business ndash no more, no less.Thus, Scotland doesnrsquot need an extension to the jobs furlough schemeto allow a lot of its working population to continue cowering in politically and media whipped-up fear about the risk of catching Covid-, but rather, a proportionately managed full opening of our economy with politicians realistically accepting that there will be a certain amount ofcontinuing Covid- infection and, in unfortunate cases, death.We already do this for all other health risks so let us not gullibly accept the politically and media manufactured narrative of the apocalypse: itrsquos not happening, and it never was going to happen ndash because we manage the risk, as we have always done.Philip Adams, Crosslee.JAMIE Black erroneously compares Covid- to cancer, heart disease and stroke.The dference which should be blatantly obvious is that Covid- is the only one of the aforementioned that is infectious.You cannot catch cancer, heart disease or a stroke from another person.David Clark, Tarbolton.NICOLA Sturgeon is trying to look both ways at the same time. The coronavirus is still on the rise despite her constantly re-emphasising her "Facts" messaging yet she is continuing her re-opening of some facilities, albeit at a rather slow pace and doing her usual sleight of hand manoeuvre by announcing dates for others but some time away. She is being hamstrung by the necessity to retain her cautious image yet appear to be concerned for the economy. It simply falls flat in the middle. Scotland is in recession yet she is doing little to ease this.In the background the war drums for independence are beating louder. Any "soft" voter who has been persuaded by Ms Sturgeons apparently good performance will soon be lost as the frailty of Scotlands position becomes clearer.Independence is the last thing Scotland needs, what we need is a coherent and dynamic economic action plan. We are not getting it.Dr Gerald Edwards, Glasgow G.PAUL McPhailobviously has no idea about the costs of television broadcasting.He complains about the First Minister appearing on our screens to give updates on coronavirus, suggesting the cost to each viewer is "wholly unjustied."What about the cost to our liveswe are not kept informed Does he not understand in times of crisis, thats what the leader of a government is expected to do As for the cost of an hour on TV ndash and dont forget, all other news media are feeding into this to get their stories ndash this is probably the cheapest  minutes on television. I would say the BBC accountant will be more than happy.Andy Stenton, Glasgow G.

title: letters-fairer-ways-fund-councils
story: Holyrood has the powers to determine local government structures and taxation.Effective local democracy needs effective and socially just fund-raising powers.Common Weal has suggested that Scotland should aim for local authorities to raise at least  per cent of their own revenue.No one method of local taxation is fair and, as Mr Maciver argues, local authorities could be empowered to decide on their own "basket" of taxes.Short-term steps could include widening the council tax bands and scrapping the cap on local authority council tax levels. A comprehensive revaluation should be set in hand which would give the basis both for a fairer property tax and for a land value tax, both to be introduced within five years. Local authorities should also be permitted a wider range of local taxes, which could include a tourist tax and workplace parking levies. Community councils should be enabled as of right to levy a small precept on the council tax instead of being dependent on local authority handouts. The balance of council income would come from the Scottish Government, which controls income tax levels, and would be at a iable level so that richer areas would receive less per head of population than poorer areas.This approach, primarily taxing land, property and income, would mean that Scotland could have a fairer and more progressive taxation system even within the constraints laid down by Westminster.David Mumford, Dunbar.NOT SO GREENYOU report on SSE Renewable`s new Viking wind farm near Shetland. As usual, there will be little use of Scottish labour and the turbines themselves will be installed and manufactured by a foreign company, in this case Vestas from Denmark Business, August . We are, as always, advised that some work will be offered to local labour but by far, the bulk of the turbine installation and manufacture goes to other countries.Wind turbines are always being promoted as green energy, but no thought has been given to the amount of fossil fuel used in their manufacture nor transport and installation. Another major cost, overlooked on all of their promotion, is the cost of decommissioning after the  to -year lespan and the subsequent disposable of currently unrecyclable turbine blades, the bulk being taken to landfill.George Dale, Beith.GAELIC FOLLYIT seems the force feeding of Gaelic continues apace. South Ayrshire Council staff are to be told to adopt Gaelic email signatures. South Ayrshire is ranked th for the number of Gaelic speakers . So here is todayrsquos new fun game. Translate the following into English:a Tha iad air a rsquochuilbheart a chall gu turb An urrainn dhuinn cuidhteas Comhairle Siorrachd Agraveir a Deas a-nis If you are one of the .% minority Gaelic speakers you can blame Googleitrsquos not quite the way Macdonald of MacDonald might have said it. Non-Gaelic readers can probably recognise council incompetence and misplaced priorities in any language. Slagraveinte.John Dunlop, Ayr.

title: newburgh-primary-school-nursery-closes-child-tests-positive-covid-19
story: The pupil at Newburgh Primary School and Nursery is said to be self-isolating at home with other relatives for the next two weeks.Health bosses confirmed that the nursery is closed for a deep clean, but say the rest f the school remains open for older children.Anyone who came into contact with the confirmed case has been contacted by Test and Protect teams and are isolating for  days.:In full: Scotlands primary and secondary schools where there are cases of Covid-Shelagh Mclean, Fe Councilrsquos head of education and childrenrsquos services, told the Daily Record: ldquoWe are following public health advice and talking with our colleagues in NHS Fe about actions required regarding Covid-.ldquoWith their direction, we are taking all appropriate actions, including that relating to Test and Protect and contact with any confirmed case linked to one of our schools.ldquoA joint letter, from us and the NHS, was issued to all parents and carers in Fe at the end of last week to keep them informed.ldquoWersquove also issued a comprehensive list of questions and answers to help with any questions that they may have, and reminded them of their responsibilities around quarantining at www.fe.gov. uk schoolcovidfaqsLynn Burnett, nurse consultant in health protection, said: ldquoWe appreciate that members of the public may be concerned about any new community cases, however we want to reassure people that the risk of contracting coronavirus remains low.ldquoNHS Fe has well-established procedures in place to trace those in close contact with the case and our public health contact tracing team is currently calling those who came into prolonged contact with the confirmed case to offer support and advice.

title: eusebis-glasgow-first-stock-dolce-gabbana-wine
story: Eusebi Deli in the citys west end will serve Rosa by Sicilian winemaker Donnafugata, which has a financial partnership with thecelebrated designers.Inspired by Sicily, an area said to beclose to the designersrsquo hearts, thepink wine was born from a  vintage and mixed two of the islandrsquos vines Nerello Mascalese and Nocera.: Recipe: Gary Townsends garlic and rosemary foccaciaThe Rallo family, who own Donnafugata,has made wine in Marsala in Sicilly since  and their ancient cellars tunnel beneath the city.Giovanna Eusebi, owner of Eusebi Deli, said: ldquoWe are very proud to be the only UK stockist of Rosa, a very special collaboration between Donnafugata and Dolce and Gabbana."Self-confessed connoisseurs will pick up on the delicate notes of jasmine and bergamot paired with sweet wild strawberry and peach providing a bouquet of flavours too good to put down."The unique roseacute wine transports me to my happy place on the Italian coast, providing some much need escapism from the current pandemic!"We recommend enjoying the wine with our hand-ed Scottish scallops with orange butter and almond dish because of its perfectly sweet flavours that nod to this Sicilian partnership.": Wine by Gerard Richardson: Perfect plonk for a Summers dayOn the new collaboration Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana said: We are Italian, we love to eat anddrinka good wine, likeRosa, born from our collaboration with Donnafugata."For us it is like tasting the smells of our land, seeing its colours again and feeling its atmosphere.Rosa is available to purchase via the Eusebi Delirsquos website or to order when dining at the restaurant.

title: face-coverings-brought-secondary-schools-limited-basis
story: Nicola Sturgeon said the government expected to recommend coverings in corridors and other communal areas, but not classrooms.She said education secretary John Swinney was in the final stage of consulting with unions and councils on the matter.It follows the World Health Organisation recommendingface coverings in schools for over s at the weekend.The change is expected to be agreed at todayrsquos Education Recovery Group, with detailed guidance issued tomorrow.Ms Sturgeon said: "I can confirm that the Education Secretary is in the final stages of consulting with teachers and local authorities on a recommendation for the use of face coverings by staff and pupils in secondary schools, when they are moving around in corridors and communal areas."We are consulting on this specic measure becausemixing between dferent groups is more likely in corridors and communal areas - increasing the potential for transmission."Crowding and close contact in these areas is more likely, and voices could be raised - resulting in greater potential for creating aerosol transmission."And finally, there is often less scope for effective ventilation in these areas."So this is a position, of we conclude it as we expect to do, that would reflect - and actually go slightly beyond - current WHO guidance."We are also considering the position on school transport and we will set out our conclusion in next few days."We are not currently consulting on any proposals to wear face coverings in the classroom."That is because there is greater scope for physical distancing in the classroom, and face coverings are more likely to interfere with teaching.I would emphasise, however, that where there are outbreaks, it remains an option for Incident Management Teams to recommend more extensive use of face coveringsthey believe in a particular area that is required for a period to protect public health and reduce the risk of transmission.":Face coverings in schools and Aberdeen lockdown: Key points from todays Covid- briefingJames GillespieHighSchool in Edinburgh,Grantown Grammar School in Grantown on Spey and Millburn Academy in Inverness have independentlysaidmasksneed to be worn between classes.As the daily briefing, Ms Sturgeon also announced another  positive cases of coronavirus overnight,  in NHS Tayside,  in NHS Lanarkshire,  in NHS Greater Glasgow and Clyde and five in NHS Grampian.There were no deaths overnight.Scotlandrsquos largest teaching union welcomed the move on face coverings.EIS General Secretary Larry Flanagan said: ldquoThe EIS continues to believe that effective physical distancing is the best means of reducing the risk of COVID- spread in schools.ldquoWe are continuing to press the Scottish Government for more staff and smaller classes to achieve this. We note the WHO advice on face coverings for those aged  and over, where m distancing cant be maintained.ldquoIn situations where physical distancing is dficult, for example in busy corridors when pupils are moving between classes, use of face coverings becomes more important and we welcome the current Scottish Government consultation on this issue."However the Us for Them parents group warned against mandatory face coverings in schools.Jo Bisset, organiserforUsforThemScotland, said: "Everyone appreciates the health and safety of pupils and teachers has to be a priority.ldquoButforcing children to wear masks when therersquos little,any, scientic evidence to support such a move could be hugely damaging.ldquoIt could have an extremely negative impact on pupils with autism, hearing impairments and conditions such as asthma.ldquoWe also have to consider those children from unstable households who simply wonrsquot be sent to school with any mask, let alone one that is safe and effective.ldquoParents want to get their children back to school andforthat experience to be as normal as it possibly can be.ldquoForced wearing of masks in the classroom, or when moving about the building, would not achieve any sense of normalityforchildren whorsquove endured quite enough in recent months.ldquoParents want the Scottish Government and councils to rule out this move now so they can get on with assisting their children back into the school routine.:Huge Covid- outbreak at Scots school as  staff and three pupils test positive for virusScottish Liberal Democrat leader Willie Rennie said:ldquoThis change of policy is the right thing to do and will provide an extra barrier of protection from the virus and reassurance to staff, pupils and parents.ldquoThe reality on the ground in Scotlandrsquos schools was outpacing the governmentrsquos policy and with the World Health Organisation recommending face coverings between classes and in other parts of the school estate this move is the right one.Green MSP Ross Greersaid:ldquoI am pleased that the Scottish Government is finally moving to encourage the wearing of face coverings in schools."The Greens first proposed this in June and consistently pressed the Government over the summer to strengthen their guidance, including last week at First Ministerrsquos Questions.ldquoThere is clear evidence that face coverings signicantly reduce transmission of the virus, so it is disappointing that itrsquos taken the government so long to hear teachersrsquo concerns, rather than make this inevitable change before schools reopened.ldquoI am confused as to why the First Minister thinks masks should be worn in corridors but not classrooms though."She canrsquot have spent much time in high schools recentlyshe thinks social distancing is going on in classes of twenty to thirty teenagers when the classrooms are no bigger than they were in March.

title: face-coverings-schools-aberdeen-lockdown-key-points-todays-covid-19-briefing
story: She updated Scots on todays figures, and said  people tested positive for the virus overnight, with no new deaths recorded.Here are four key points from todays briefing:Face coverings will soon become mandatory within secondary schools. Nicola Sturgeon suggested masks in corridors and communal areas should come into force.The First Minister said the Education Secretary is in the final stages of consultation with teachers regarding the use.Nicola Sturgeon said that changes will be "very welcome" after easing restrictions put on Aberdeen in response to a Covid- cluster.The five-mile recreational travel limit, along with care home and hospital visiting rule changes were lted on Monday.Ms Sturgeon thanked local health professionals and the people of Aberdeen for their compliance with the measures.The outbreak at a  Sisters food processing factory has been described as "very signicant" by the First Minister.There were cases linked to the cluster as of Sunday ndash  employees and  close contacts.The number of cases should be expected to rise further, according to Ms Sturgeon.The First Minister addressed the cluster at a school in Dundee where  people have tested positive.Three pupils and  staff members are among those who have tested positive at Kingspark School.Ms Sturgeon saidchildren from two other Dundee schools have tested positive, and she stressedpupils and staff must stick to self-isolating guidance they have received.

title: tories-propose-mackays-law-kick-absentee-msps
story: Tory MSP Graham Simpson said he planned to bring forward a ldquoMackayrsquos Law to remove MSPs who fail to take part in parliamentary proceedings for six months.A similar rule already applies to councillors, however there is no equivalent for MSPs.Mr Mackay resigned on the eve of the Scottish budget on February  after the Scottish Sun revealed he had been pestering a -year-old schoolboy on social media.The paper reported the -year-old MSP had contacted the boy out of the blue without knowing his age the previous August, then sent him  messages over six months.Mr Mackay, who came out as gay in , had been tipped as a future First Minister until the scandal abruptly ended his political career.The Renfrewshire North and West MSP has not been seen at Holyrood since, and the SNP is now in the process of selecting a new candidate for his seat in .However by continuing as a nominal Independent MSP for more than six months, Mr Mackay has so far received more than pound, in salary.He was also paid an automatic severance payment of pound, for loss of ministerial office.His conduct has prompted calls for new mechanisms to remove errant MSPs or those who neglect their duties, such as the election petition that applies to MPs.Mr Simpson said he intended to introduce a private members bill in the next parliament which would mean any MSP who failed to show up to Holyrood for six months could no longer remain as a member of the Scottish ParliamentWith more Holyrood business being conducted online because of coronavirus, any MSPs would took part in virtual proceedings would not be caught by such a law.Mr Simpson said: ldquoMost councils have rules on this andDerek Mackay was a councillor and hadnrsquot done his job for six months then he would have been drummed out.ldquoBut there are no rules covering MSPsrsquo attendance, which means they can do nothing and pocket the cash.ldquoIn theory, you could act like Derek Mackay is currently doing for five years. That is just wrong.ldquoIf you are elected to the Scottish Parliament you should be a worker not a shirker. Nothing  should be allowed.ldquoIf Mr Mackay had any honour left he would stand down now and allow the people of Renfrewshire North and West to elect someone who will properly represent them.The ScottishLiberal Democrats, whohave also advocated the removal of wayward MSPs, said it was an "interesting idea".A spokesperson said: "For some time we have favoured a system of recall which has been debated and discussed."We still hope we can persuade other parties to support it."The six-month rule is an interesting idea which is worthy of further consideration."ScottishLabour Business Manager Elaine Smith said:ldquoScottish Labour agrees with the principles behind this proposal and supports any action taken to hold MSPs, such as Derek Mackay, that continually fail to fulfil their duties as representatives to account.ldquoHowever, we must have provisions put in place to ensure MSPs who are absent from the chamber for six months for health, family or other legitimate reasons are not penalised for their absence.

title: furlough-no-plans-extend-scheme-businesses-closed-law
story: A Downing Street spokesman confirmed that the job-saving scheme is still set to be wound up by the end of October, despite mounting pressure to introduce a sector-specic plan.Labour and the SNP have both called for the Chancellor to extend the scheme to some areas, in particular those subject to local lockdowns and industries which have been worst hit by the pandemic.This includes manufacturing, retail and aviation.Today the Night Time Industries Association said afor clubs and venues is possiblenumbers inside are limited, social distancing takes place and clubbers wear face masks.Their report stated: "Use of face coverings on the dancefloor can be implemented and enforced through existing security staff and protocols.It also warned % of businesses in the sector could be closed by next month without more support. as the sector reaches a "critical point".Michael Kill, chief executive of the association, said: "We have now reached a critical point. In the absence of a clear reopening strategy from government, or the promise of financial support, huge numbers of businesses within our industry are facing financial collapse and thousands of job losses."The report clearly shows that there is a case for the safe reopening of night-time leisure venues, including nightclubs, late night bars, live music venues and event spaces."Whilst many of these are large capacity venues, it is important to note that they already have many of the safety protocols in place to mitigate the spread of Covid-."We implore the government to give us the opportunity to reopen in a safe, risk-assessed way."Last week Donald Macleod, who owns Glasgows Garage and Cathouse nightclubs, spoke of his fears of job losses and industry demisemore support was not given by the Scottish Government to help the night time economy.He said the furlough scheme alone was not enough to sustain the sector, and urged officials to step in.However Rishi Sunak has insisted it is unfair to continue the furlough scheme and give workers  hope about employment opportunities once it comes to an end.When askedfirms which are required to close by law would be able to use the furlough scheme after October st, a Downing street spokesman said: ""The chancellor has been clear when the furlough scheme comes to an end, but as I say we have provided support for businesses which they are able to use, and obviously we will continue to keep that under review."The treasury and the chancellor have set out support packages which ensure llots of these sorts of high risk areas will have received. We will keep it under continuous review but the chancellor has set out the support packages available to businesses."

title: green-light-100m-economy-boosting-joint-government-deal
story: The multi-million pound plan to boost the economy has been given the green light in Moray.Officials including Michael Matheson MSP and Iain Stewart MP signed the deals heads of terms agreement this morning, moving the plan a step forward.It signals a combined investment in the area of more than poundm, with projects receiving investment including the Grant Lodge visitor attraction in Elgin, a manufacturing base and a digital health and care centre in Moray.The area is currently represented in Westminster by new Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross, and in Holyrood by the SNPs Richard Lochhead.It is also where Boris Johnson chose to visit earlier this summer, becoming the first PM since Margaret Thatcher to do so.Moray council leader Graham Leadbitter welcomed the deal, saying it was "needed more than ever to help the local economy recover in the long-term from the COVID- crisis.Iain Stewart MP, Parliamentary Under Secretary of State for Scotland for the UK Government said:ldquoEarlier this month I was delighted to announce the UK Government are investing poundm in the Moray Aerospace, Advanced Technology and Innovation Campus, which will create a pathway to skilled aviation engineering jobs for Morayrsquos residents.ldquoWith todayrsquos landmark signing of the pound million Moray Growth Deal I am pleased to confirm that the UK Governmentrsquos pound. million deal investment will also support the development of Grant Lodge - a visitor attraction in Elgin a Manufacturing Innovation base for Moray and a digital health and care cluster at Moray College.ldquoWorking together with the Scottish Government and local partners, we will deliver the prosperity and opportunities that the people of Moray deserve.ldquoCity Region and Growth Deals will be crucial to getting Scotlandrsquos economy back on track after the coronavirus pandemic and the UK Government has committed more than pound. billion to Growth Deals across every part of Scotland to secure the future of our economy.Michael Matheson MSP, Cabinet Secretary for Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity at the Scottish Government said: "Today marks an important milestone for the Moray Growth Deal, the signing of the Heads of Terms agreement and the confirmation of the projects supported by the pound. million the Scottish Government is investing in the deal."This will be invested in projects, designed by local partners, that can deliver on local priorities, re-invigorating the regional economy, and I appreciate all the hard work that Moray Council and their partners have put in to get us to this point.ldquoInvestments through the deal will create new jobs, protect existing jobs and extend economic opportunities to communities, businesses and iniduals across the region."At a time of such economic uncertainty and challenge, the projects and investment committed through the deal will be more important than ever."We will work with Moray Council over the coming months, to help them develop the projects to unlock investment and drive inclusive growth across the area as swtly as possible.Depute Chief Executive of Moray Council and lead officer for the Moray Growth Deal, Rhona Gunn, said the signing was a red-letter day for the area, adding that more work now had to be done to boost the case for the projects involved.She said: "ldquoWe still have much to do, and this work starts immediately to strengthen the business cases of each project and help shape the final outcomes. I and everyone  will be rolling up our sleeves to deliver this vision for Morayrsquos future prosperity.

title: downing-street-comments-bbc-plans-drop-rule-britannia-last-night-proms
story: It was revealed that the BBC is said to be discussing whether to drop Rule Britannia! and Land Of Hope And Glory from the finale.The Sunday Times said organisers fear a backlash because of the perceived association the traditional anthems have with colonialism and slavery.:Opinion: Mark Smith: Anti-Scottish  I think Irsquom finally facing up to my prejudiceNow Downing Street has entered into the controversy, while Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said he had written to the BBC over the issue.Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory are highlights of the Last Night of the PromsShare concerns of many about their potential removal and have raised this with @BBCConfident forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history, they add to itmdash Oliver DowdenAugust , The Prime Minister believes in tackling the ldquosubstance not the ldquosymbols of problems, a Number  spokesman said.ldquoThis is a decision and a matter for the organisers of the Proms and the BBC, the spokesman said.ldquoBut the PM previously has set out his position on like issues and has been clear that while he understands the strong emotions involved in these discussions, we need to tackle the substance of problems, not the symbols.Culture Secretary Mr Dowden said that ldquoconfident, forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history.He wrote on Twitter: ldquoRule Britannia! and Land of Hope and Glory are highlights of the Last Night of the Proms.ldquo Share concerns of many about their potential removal and have raised this withBBC.ldquoConfident forward-looking nations donrsquot erase their history, they add to it.Dalia Stasevska, from Finland, is conducting the Last Night this year, with soprano Golda Schultz and the BBC Symphony Orchestra performing.Actor Laurence Fox, who regularly criticises the BBC, wrote: ldquoI feel so honoured to be British and part of the incredible and erse modern nation we have become.ldquoWithout the past, we wouldnrsquot be where we are today. I wish the BBC would stop hating Britain so much. #DefundTheBBC.:Last Night of the Proms brought to a rousing finale with patriotic splendourBrexit Party leader Nigel Farage wrote: ldquoSo the BBC may drop Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory from The Proms because the Finnish conductor is too woke. Why not drop her instead  So the BBC may drop Rule Britannia and Land of Hope and Glory from The Proms because the Finnish conductor is too woke. Why not drop her instead mdash Nigel FarageAugust , The BBC said in a statement: ldquoWe are still finalising arrangements for the Last Night Of Rhe Proms so that we are able to respond to the latest advice in regards to Covid- and deliver the best offering possible for audiences.ldquoWe have announced that conductor Dalia Stasevska, soprano Golda Schultz and the BBC Symphony Orchestra will perform at the Last Night Of The Proms this year. Full details will be announced nearer the time of the concert .Wasfi Kani, chief executive of Grange Park Opera in Surrey, told The Sunday Times she would supportthe removal of the songs.ldquoI donrsquot listen to Land Of Hope And Glory and say lsquothank God Irsquom Britishrsquo. It actually makes me feel more alienated. Britain raped India and that is what that song is celebrating, she said.

title: worldwide-covid-19-vaccination-rollout-in-interest-countries--
story: Dr Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus warned against ldquovaccine nationalism and said global competition to create one could lead to prices spiking ldquoexponentially, which would only prolong the virus.Instead, he urged countries to support the Covax vaccines facility, which has the ldquolargest and most erse Covid- vaccine portfolio in the world.He told a WHO press briefing on Monday that  countries were ldquoengaging with the mechanism, which aims to deliver at least two billion vaccine doses by the end of .Dr Tedros said: ldquoWersquore working with vaccine manufacturers to provide all countries that join the effort timely and equitable access to all vaccines, licensed and approved.:Covid-: Indias coronavirus cases pass  millionldquoThis doesnrsquot just pool risk, it also means that prices will be kept as low as possible.ldquoNew research outlines that global competition for vaccine doses could lead to prices spiking exponentially in comparison to collaborative efforts, such as the Covax facility.ldquoIt would also lead to a prolonged pandemic as only a small number of countries would get most of the supply. Vaccine nationalism only helps the virus.Covax aims to ensure that low, middle and high-income countries all receive the vaccine in a ldquotimely way as soon as there is enough supply, Dr Tedros said.However, he warned that the schemersquos success hinged not only on countries signing up to it, but also ldquofilling key funding gaps for research and development work, and to support the lower-income economies involved."Our only way out of this #COVID pandemic is together."-@DrTedrosmdash World Health Organization August , ldquoThis is in the interests of all countries, even those that have invested with inidual manufacturers independently, Dr Tedros said.The WHO previously said the UK was one of several countries that had submitted ldquoexpressions of interest in the programme.Nine vaccines are currently part of the Covax portfolio, while discussions were ongoing with four other producers, Dr Tedros said.The scheme is being led by WHO, the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovationsand the vaccine alliance Gavi.Health workers, those over , and people with certain diseases who are most at risk of dying with coronavirus will be the first to receive a vaccine, Dr Tedros added.ldquoAs supply increases, the next stage of the vaccine rollout would be expanded based on an assessment of each countryrsquos vulnerability to the virus, he said.:Furlough: No plans to extend scheme for businesses closed by lawldquoIn order to be able to secure enough doses to rollout the vaccines, the next step for the partnership is for countries to make binding commitments in support of the Covax facility.He said more funding was ldquourgently needed to move the ldquovaccine portfolio forward.Bruce Aylward, senior adviser to WHOrsquos director general, said countries need to submit an ldquoexpression of intent to join Covax by August , followed by confirmation of intent by September , and to have ldquoinitial payments in place by October .

title: coronavirus-scientists-claim-first-human-reinfected-covid-19
story: Researchers at the University of Hong KongrsquosLi Ka Shing Faculty of Medicine used genome sequencing to show that the patient had been infected by two ldquoclearly dferent virus strains.The patient is an ldquoapparently young and healthy -year-old man residing in Hong Kong.He was ing to the Asian city from Spain, travelling via the UK, when he was found to be positive for the coronavirus on August , .:Dossier reveals worst-case scenariono-deal Brexit and coronavirus coincideThe man had previously tested positive for the virus on March , , and was hospitalised with the disease three days later.He was discharged from hospital on April  following two negative tests for Covid- taken  hours apart.Researchers reported that the patient remained asymptomatic throughout his second infection, which occurred  days after the first.Experts cautioned against jumping to conclusions based on one single case but acknowledged the discovery was a concern.Announcing the result, researchers said: "An apparently young and healthy patient had a second episode of Covid- infection which was diagnosed . months after the first episode."This case illustrates that reinfection can occur just after a few months of recovery from the first infection. Our findings suggest that SARS-CoV- may persist in the global human population as is the case for other common-cold associated human coronaviruses, evenpatients have acquired immunity via natural infection.ldquoSince the immunity can be short lasting after natural infection, vaccination should also be considered for those with one episode of infection.ldquoPatients with previous Covid- infection should also comply with epidemiological control measures such as universal masking and social distancing.The scientists add that, as immunity may be short-lasting, any vaccine should be administered to everyone, including those who have already been infected.If the research, published in the medical journalClinical Infectious Diseases, is correct it means thatherd immunity is ldquounlikely to be able to eliminate Covid-, and it will probably ldquocontinue to circulate through the population as ldquoseasonal coronaviruses do.Furthermore, they recommend that even those who have recovered from Covid-, and so are assumed to be unable to transmit the virus, should ldquocomply with epidemiological control measures such as universal masking and social distancing.:Coronavirus LIVE: Face coverings set to become mandatory in high school corridorsResponding to the study on Twitter, Yale School of Medicines Professor Akiko Iwasaki wrote: "Kudos to the scientists for this study. This is no cause for alarm - this is a textbook example of how immunity should work."Second infection was asymptomatic. While immunity was not enough to block re-infection, it protected the person from disease."Patient had no detectable antibody at the time of re-infection but developed detectable antibody after re-infection. This is encouraging."Since re-infection can occur, herd immunity by natural infection is unlikely to eliminate #SARSCoV. The only safe and effective way to achieve herd immunity is through vaccination."Lastly, while this is a good example of how primary infection can prevent disease from subsequent infection, more studies are needed to understand the range of outcomes from reinfection."The research was led by Dr Kelvin Kai-Wang To, Professor Ivan Fan-Ngai Hung, and Professor Kwok-Yung Yuen.Dr David Strain, from the University of Exeter said: ldquoThis is a worrying finding for several reasons. The first, as is laid out in this manuscript, is that it suggests that previous infection is not protective. The second is that it raises the possibility that vaccinations may not provide the hope that we have been waiting for.ldquoVaccinations work by simulating infection to the body, thereby allowing the body to develop antibodies. If antibodies dont provide lasting protection, we will need to revert to a strategy of viral near-elimination in order toto a more normal le.

title: handing-power-attorney-can-strengthen-close-bonds
story: One of the most enduring myths that humans perpetuate is that of the indestructability of their nearest and dearest: parents, grandparents and friends. True, le expectancy in the UK has increased steadily for decades, though the Office for National Statistics points out that it has signicantly levelled off since .And the current pandemic has jolted us all into a new sense of urgency, with increasing numbers deciding to make a will ndash a rise accompanied by a new interest in the power of attorney, which anticipates the possibility that someone, for reasons of age or health, may have to allow another to deal with their affairs.Scott Ewart, managing partner at Glasgow-based legal services firm Thomas Bradley and Co, believes that granting power of attorney is arguably even more important than making a will.ldquoSomeone losing capacity without having appointed an attorney ndash someone who can formally act on their behalf ndash could end up in a terrible situation.ldquoPeople often assume that when they write a will and appoint an executor, that person ndash often one of their children ndash will deal with all those issues including power of attorney but thats not the case, he says.ldquoWe can advise them about the dference between a will, which takes care of your affairs after you have passed away and a power of attorney that ensures your affairs are taken care of should you lose the capacity to manage them yourself.There are two types of power of attorney in Scotland: that relating to financial property affairs which you can decide to begin immediately or onlyyou become incapable and welfare power of attorney, which allows someone to make welfare decisions for you should you lose the capacity to make these decisions.Incapacity, Ewart points out, can affect the simplest aspects of le. ldquoPeople tend to think in terms of a crisis, such as someone being affected by Alzheimerrsquos, but power of attorney can be important for someone who is just struggling physically, he says.ldquoI think of my grandmother who at  is mentally as sharp as a tack but set up a power of attorney as through illness she simply wasnrsquot able get out to take care of basic essentials such as going to the post office for her pension. Someone may also need their son or daughter to make sure gas or electricity bills are looked after and that the shopping is done.Which means that the person granted powers of attorney must be someone you can trust implicitly ndash and someone who also feels comfortable with acting formally on anotherrsquos behalf. Some people find it dficult to discuss with a parent that they face losing capacity through an illness."So the right person isnrsquot just someone you trust but someone who can also handle the potential emotional stress of a being an attorney, he says.Appointing an attorney can be a sensitive matter but the person granted power can subsequently be altered. ldquoPeople can and do come to us after several years ndash and after circumstances have altered ndash to change the person in whom power of attorney resides or add someone , but most people tend to appoint their children or grandchildren, he says.ldquoAnd they try to share the responsibility between two or three people, making the person best able to deal with their affairs the primary attorney, with one or two substitutes.ldquoIf there are no substitutes in place and the principal attorney passes away or moves to another country after the person who has appointed them loses capacity then no one  can be appointed, he adds.The Office of the Public provides the registration service for powers of attorney and can help people who have no knowledge of whatrsquos involved. Ewart explains: ldquoTherersquos a lot of support for the many people who initially have no idea what to do and the OPG ensures that people who grant powers of attorney or put them in place are protected and that trust companies are doing their job properly.ldquoIt receives a one-off fee for that and is always there to give general advice on what you should or shouldnrsquot do, thoughlegal or financial advice is needed you should consult an appropriate adviser.And while itrsquos possible for an inidual to set up a power of attorney, Ewart says itrsquos a complicated process that involves solicitors and GPs ensuring that multiple documents are signed off correctly by the persons family members. ldquoEngaging a professional who can complete the process online removes the most onerous part of the exercise, making sure itrsquos dated, checked and signed off correctly and most importantly, that itrsquos registered, he says.The company has seen a signicant increase in requests for powers of attorney: ldquoItrsquos becoming a priority for more people and % to % of the people we talk to about wills every month now set up a power of attorney at the same time.He says that while this does not represent a major financial decision, many people are seeing their incomes squeezed at the moment so Thomas Bradley is currently halving its price for the service. ldquoWhile recognising that ndash like every other company ndash we must make money I feel we have an obligation not to have profits solely in mind at the moment and offer a service thatrsquos affordable. If wersquore going to do something positive for the community, now is the time to do it.thomasbradleyco

story: coronavirusChange of opening hours at OIC receptionAugust ,  at : am vw, px"  A temporary change to the opening hours of the OIC’s reception desk is to be put in place tomorrow, Monday.Due to operational issues as a result of COVID-,  the switchboard and reception desk will now require to be closed to the public between -pm, Monday to Friday.To compensate for the closure during the lunchtime period, the council will open the reception each day until pm rather than pm.  Emergency contact numbers will be available on the recorded message via   and on  www.orkney.gov.ukThe revised opening hours will be as follows:However, folk are asked to only attend in person for essential business and to continue, whenever possible, to use other methods of contact such as online   via www.orkney.gov.uk MyOrkney, by email customerservice@orkney.gov.uk or by phone .An OIC spokeswoman said: #Additional safety measures remain in place and we would ask that anyone experiencing symptoms of COVID-, or anyone who has been in contact with a person infected with the virus does not enter the building.#Customers who need to see an officer are asked to make an appointment ahead of the visit. title: cursiter quarry extension rejected by planning committee
story: An application to extend Cursiter Quarry in Firth has been rejected by Orkney Islands Council#s planning committee, today, Wednesday.The application, put forward by OIC#s development and infrastructure department, received letters of objection from four residents living in the nearby area. It proposed further extraction of stone from the quarry as well as landscaping and restoration on the site.This was the second hearing of this application by the planning committee. A decision had previously been deferred, pending a site visit by councillors.Consideration was given by committee members to the proposal made by the development and infrastructure department, as well as the concerns raised by objectors. Reasons for objection included:After a y discussion, councillors chose to reject the application. This decision was led by Kirkwall East councillor, David Dawson, who was seconded by West Mainland councillor, Owen Tierney. The reasoning given for this was that the application proposed an extension which extended beyond the quarry#s defined mineral safeguard area, which Councillor Dawson and his colleagues felt was not justied. It was also felt that this extension would result in cumulative adverse impacts to residents living in nearby properties.Though this rejection was unanimously agreed by the planning committee, Kirkwall East councillor, John Ross Scott, formally lodged his objection to the decision taken by members after it had been made.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: local livestock association enters in to new partnership
story: Orkney Livestock Associationhave signed up to partner with the Moredun scientic institute to give their members access to research outputs, knowledge, skills and expertise generated by the Organisation.OLA is a farmer-led organisation aimed at improving the health of Orkney’s cattle herds.  The scheme was officially launched in February  with a programme to eradicate BVD and a Johne’s eradication scheme followed in November . The new partnership will allow OLA#s members access to Moredun’s members area with a wealth of livestock health information, including the full range of technical news sheets, and will also promote working together on joint events and initiatives.The work of the Moredun scientic institute have made a major impact both in the UK and globally, due in a large part to the unique relationship it has had has with the farming community and the emphasis the organisation puts on effective knowledge exchange with livestock producers.Retired local vet Willie Stewart, who is the chairman of Moredun’s North of Scotland Regional Advisors Board said:“The Moredun Research Institute is a world leader in the development of livestock vaccines, animal disease tests and control plans. I believe that OLA representing the cattle industry in Orkney can have a strong association with Moredun in the future.#Beth Wells, from Moredun, said “Through meetings we have been fortunate to meet many of Orkney’s livestock farmers, who are well known for their high quality beef production and we are delighted to be developing a closer working collaboration with OLA, which will be of huge benefit to both of our organisations.”OLA is a sub-group of HiHealth Herdcare which is a national cattle health scheme. Karen Johnston, from OLA, said: “We are delighted and very honoured to give our members the opportunity to benefit from expert information and support from such a prestigious and well respected organisation.  We are looking forward to seeing how this partnership progresses and the benefits it brings to Orkney farmers.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur calls for paramedic students bursary
story: newsMcArthur calls for paramedic students# bursaryAugust ,  at : amOrkney MSP, Liam McArthur has pressed the Scottish Government to commit to introducing a bursary scheme to support student paramedics.During First Minister’s Questions, yesterday, Thursday, Mr McArthur highlighted that Scottish students studying to become paramedics are asked to work the same hours as a fully qualied paramedic during the course of their degree.According to the Orkney MSP, this makes part time work almost impossible, yet trainee paramedics are not given bursary funding in recognition of this.Mr McArthur has previously raised this with the Scottish Government but was told that there were no plans to amend the funding options.In response, the First Minister acknowledged the case being made and gave an assurance that the government would continue to consider how better support could be made available to trainee paramedics.Following the exchange, Mr McArthur said: “Paramedics play a vital role within our NHS, but this is not reflected in the support they are given to become qualied.“Like student nurses and midwives, trainee paramedics now need to complete a degree course while also working similar hours to a fully qualied paramedic. Unlike student nurses and midwives, however, those training to be a paramedic are not eligible for a bursary, despite being unable to take up part time work.  To add insult to injury, their counterparts in England do receive bursaries.“This lack of a level playing field risks putting off those we need to see coming into our health service.  The current arrangements do little to encourage young people to pursue a career as a paramedic and store up problems for the future.“When I wrote to the Health Secretary recently on behalf of a constituent, I was told the government has no plans to review the funding options for trainee paramedics. Today, Nicola Sturgeon said she would look into the matter, having also been approached by a young constituent, angry at the unequal treatment.“The First Minister needs to recognise that introducing a bursary scheme would make a real dference, not least in widening access to the profession.  It’s time the Scottish Government properly recognised the dedication of our trainee paramedics by putting them on the same footing as trainee nurses and midwives.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mcarthur demands clarity on ret timeline
story: newsMcArthur demands clarity on RET timelineAugust ,  at : pmOrkney MSP, Liam McArthur has demanded clarity from the Scottish Government on when Road Equivalent Tarfwill be delivered on Pentland Firth routes.During Portfolio Questions, today, Thursday, Mr McArthur pressed the island minister, Paul Wheelhouse to confirm a date for its introduction now that the courts and European Commission appear to have removed any objections to it proceeding.Mr McArthur believes that cheaper fares should have been implemented on Northern Isles routes over two years ago, and has repeated calls for ministers to commit the underspend from this delay to reduce fares on Orkney’s internal ferry services.In response, Mr Wheelhouse confirmed that the Scottish Government were continuing to engage with the European Commission on options for introducing RET but said that this work had been paused because of the COVID- pandemic.Following the exchange, Mr McArthur said: “For over a decade those travelling on ferry routes to the Western Isles have benefited from cheaper ferry fares while Orkney has been excluded.“During this time, the excuses from Ministers may have changed but sadly not the experience for many using these leline routes. On the Pentland Firth, people are still being forced to pay over the odds.“COVID has inevitably created challenges, but even prior to the pandemic there seemed to be little urgency from the Scottish Government to deliver on its promise. Assurances that Ministers will now ‘pick up the ball again’ are likely to ring hollow with islanders who just want a date for cheaper fares to be introduced.“Meantime, Ministers could help soften the blow from the delayed introduction of RET by using the underspend to cut fares on Orkney’s internal ferry services. At the very least this would prevent funds earmarked for Orkney being redirected to transport projects where in Scotland.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: scotland remains in phase three but more activities to resume
story: coronavirusScotland remains in Phase Three — but more activities to resumeAugust ,  at : pmScotland is to remain in Phase Three of its lockdown exit plan — but facilities such as gyms and swimming pools will be allowed to open from August , First Minister Nicola Sturgeon has announced, this afternoon, Thursday.The reopening of bingo halls, and the restarting of outdoor contact sports and live events and driving lessons will be allowed from next Monday, August .#On balance, taking account of dferent harms that COVID and the restrictions imposed to tackle it are inflicting on the country, we have proposed that reopenings pencilled in for August  can proceed,# Ms Sturgeon said.#I must stress, though, that such reopenings must only happen when the appropriate guidance covering that activity or setting has been implemented.#We will also monitor the impact carefully, and we will not hesitate to reimpose restrictions, should that prove necessary.#She added that, subject to guidance being in place, indoor swimming and gym facilities will also be able to reopen from August .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: tenth case linked to orkney covid cluster
story: breaking newsTenth case linked to Orkney COVID clusterAugust ,  at : pmA tenth crew member has tested positive for COVID- in the Orkney fishing vessel cluster, NHS Orkney’s Director of Public Health Dr Louise Wilson confirmed today, Friday.This was disclosed in her update to the multi-agency Incident Management Team , this afternoon.The crew member is in isolation on the Scottish mainland and being monitored by the relevant health boardAs he does not live in Orkney, this new case will not be reflected in the Scottish Government COVID figures for the isles.Dr Wilson said the IMT would meet again only when there was new information to report. “All contacts of those involved in this cluster have now been traced but we will continue to monitor the situation,” she said.Dr Wilson reminded the Orkney community that near neighbour, Aberdeen, was still in lockdown and not to become complacent about the spread of COVID-.“By following the FACTS guidance, a person decreases their risk of contracting and passing on the virus,” she added.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: mareel to open its cinema at reduced capacity and with no new blockbusters
story: Film fans have been told to  expect changes when Mareel opens its cinema again later this week.Jenny Leask, film programme manager, said that while she was #absolutely delighted# to be reopening on Friday, there would also be restrictions.Writing in a blog, Ms Leask said films would only be showing in cinema one as physical distancing requirement meant it was not practical to reopen cinema two. As a result, fewer films will be on show, to begin with.Ms Leask also said regular slots, such as Screen Horizons # which showcases independent and world cinema, classic films and documentaries # will not be running, although they are hoped to#as soon as possible#. on release as, due to the distribution deal, it would be the only film we could show for two weeks, and we want to cater for as many of you as possible,# she added.#No new titles have been released in the summer, with all the cinemas closed, but there were plenty of films we were scheduled to show before lockdown so we#re now able to catch up with those.#I#ve tried to include a wide iety of films in our programme, so hopefully there#ll be something for everyone.#Bookings can only be made online until the building reopens. The system is set up to to automatically block off seats around each booking, keeping the appropriate distance between customers.Customers making group bookings are asked to ensure all the people in that group are in the same bubble –  and to book tickets at the same timethey want to sit together.Face coverings must be worn in the cinema other than when eating or drinking. Customers are asked to take their own rubbish with them at the end of the film and put it in the bins provided.Cinemas will be thoroughly cleaned between each screening and hand sanitiser is available throughout the building.#We#ll keep you posted on any new developments, and please rest assured we#re all working hard to make your visit a safe and enjoyable one,# Ms Leask said.#See you at the cinema.#..Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia.
